blocks.title: Welcome to MapStudy
blocks.ask: This is what a typical MapStudy page looks like. The left side of the window houses a map, either interactive or static as configured by the survey designer. On the right side, the participant is presented with survey questions, which may include descriptive text and other media elements.

blocks.title: Full Questions Page
blocks.ask: The window may be configured to hide the map section and only show the questions section, but not vice-versa. It also includes a static header containing a customized title and branding, and a footer with the survey designerâ€™s contact information and social media links.
Surveys often start with non-map pages, and use text inputs such as the one below to request information or consent from participants.

blocks.title: Map Library Types
blocks.ask: The library module determines which web mapping software or service will be used to render the map. The current options allow a tile-based interactive web map using the Leaflet code library, a static map image rendered directly on the page, or an HTML iframe element for rendering additional multimedia content.
At the left is an example of an interactive web map using the Leaflet library.

blocks.title: Library Type: Image
blocks.ask: Here's an example of a static, non-interactive map image.

blocks.title: Library Type: iframe
blocks.ask: And here's an example of a map image rendered from an iframe.

blocks.title: Map Types
blocks.ask:
Mapstudy includes support for four data layer techniques:
  • choropleth
  • proportional symbol
  • dot density
  • heat
  • isoline(for continuous data, not included here)
Use the Reexpress interaction operator to toggle between map types.

blocks.title: Base Layers
blocks.ask: You can include base layers from various sources, including tile services from Stamen and ESRI.
